conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the Ampere force received by wire ABC.
Wire ABC is composed of segments AB and BC, each of length L, with angle 120° between them.
Magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the paper with magnitude B.
Ampere force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by F = I L x B.
Length vector L_AB is along the direction of wire AB.
Magnetic field B is perpendicular to the plane of the paper and points inward.
Cross product L_AB x B is perpendicular to both L_AB and B.
Length vector L_BC is along the direction of wire BC.
Magnetic field B is perpendicular to the plane of the paper and points outward.
Cross product L_BC x B is perpendicular to both L_BC and B.
Total force on wire ABC is vector sum of forces on segments AB and BC.
Force on segment AB: Length is L, current is I, magnetic field is B.
Angle between L_AB and B is 0°, force magnitude F_AB = I L B sin(0°) = 0.
Force on AB is zero.
Force on segment BC: Length is L, current is I, magnetic field is B.
Angle between L_BC and B is 180°, force magnitude F_BC = I L B sin(180°) = 0.
Force on BC is zero.
Total force on wire ABC is F_total = F_AB + F_BC = 0 + 0 = 0.
Re-evaluate problem considering correct interpretation of forces.
Forces on segments AB and BC are perpendicular, resolved using vector addition.
Magnitude of force on each segment: F_AB = I L B sin(90°) = I L B, F_BC = I L B sin(90°) = I L B.
